text: 6/9/17. On tap at the Fermentaria. Its back! Brown pour with a small khaki head. Biscuit aroma, toast, black tea, caramel. Malty flavor, biscuit, toast. Not bad.
Sample from Sidebar. Toasted egg, wheat, melon and straw aroma. Cereal, toasted bread and paper flavor. Quite odd.
Draft. Amber pour. Creamy white head. Aroma is toasty and herbal. Flavor is toasty with melon.

On cask at the brewery. Pours a hazed amber with a large white head. Soft musk and a bit of citrus and hints of spicy rye on the nose. Medium bodied, sweet malt and gentle citrus comes through. Malt and crisp earthy bitterness with melon and citrus behind it. Lovely and easy drinking.

LSAT Freedom Trip Beer #15. Keg at Als of Hampden. Hazy amber, large foamy white head, good retention. Aroma of caramel, butter, spicy hops, sugared fruits. The taste is caramel, spice, butter, raisin, spicy hops. Medium bodied, lingering bitterness. Not their best.

I prefer a mediocre bitter on the hand pump to a superior one from a cold, standard tap. Intensely sweet and malty, mouthfeel completely off IMO. May be a decent beer, but just not to my liking or not presented in my preferred context.
On tap at Pizza Boy pours a hazy amber with a ring of white head. Nose has orange, caramel, malt, sort of beery. Flavor is very beery, caramel, malt, bread, soap, lemon. Watery finish. Not real good.

On tap at Pizza Boy. Pours a clear reddish brown. White head. Bready and nutty aroma. Taste is bitter and nutty with just an inkling of butter. Not getting anything different than other bitters I have had though. Maybe slightly more bitter ironically. A very beery beer.

Draft. Large white head atop lightly hazed amber body. Aroma is moderately sweet, orange, light grapefruit, light bread, gingerbread. Taste is moderately sweet, orange, some bread, light gingerbread. Light-medium body, light acidity.
Draft at the source - Pours orange white head. Nose/taste of toffee, bread, creamy caramel - medium body.

Draft at Khyber Pass. Cloudy copper pour with a thick frothy off-white head. Feels somewhat like a bitter but with enough hops to make it an IPA. Medium-full body. The rye brings some extra spice to the mix. Toffee caramels. Grassy pine resins. Toasted whole wheat bread. Dried apricots. Parsley. Tangerine peels. Wildflower honey. Cinnamon rolls. Bit of an odd mix that seems like it should not work, yet somehow does.

Cask at the brewpub. Pours semi clear amber with a medium sized head. The aroma is loaded with caramel malt, a touch of floral and piney notes. The taste has a nice bitterness, very hoppy but not really dominant. Quite fruity and has a malt profile that really balanced nicely.
Draft. Not retired anymore... Brown pour with tan head. Brown malty tone aromas. Almost like a lighter brown ale than a mild. Probably why I like it a bit.

Cask at Tired Hands Cafe with Linh. Pours a deep brown body with thin white lacing. Mouthfeel is medium and creamy with notes of round bready maltiness and soft bitterness in the finish. Pretty simple and straightforward, but a nice and drinkable bitter.
On tap at the Fermentaria. Pours a cloudy copper with very large frothy off white head that lasts. The aroma is toast and toffee. Medium mouth, very bitter, bready malt, toffee, good.

Cask at the cafe. Dark amber body, large creamy off-white head that sticks around forever, leaving behind nice frothy lacing. Super toffee, florals, toasted bread, mild citrus, and so.e grass. Medium bodied, silky carbonation, moderate bitterness, mild sweetness, rounded finish. Really nice cask bitter.

On tap, pours copper color with small white head and full lacing sheets. Nice apparrance to her. Aroma and flavor are bready malt, heated honey, geriatric mothball and grain. Not a whole lot going on with regards to flavor like most English styles but it does have some nice bitterness in the finish. Dont really taste the hops though besides the bitter close. Pretty sure this is solid but I never know with alot of them English styles.

Poured a hazy light amber color with a big fluffy head. Very nice lacing. Hops hit the nose first but are soon replaced with an earthy, bready malt essence. Sweet toffee flavors. Smooth on the palate with a lingering bitter finish.

Pours a clear amber with a medium lt tan head.  Aroma is nutty with soft chocolate notes.  Flavor follows suit...earthy/malty and bitter...chocolate creeps in.  Mouthfeel is medium/full and almost creamy with a bitter/nutty finish.

On cask at Station Taproom 2nd Anniv. party. Cask of their Special bitter dry hopped with Cascade.

Pours a cloudy golden amber with a fluffy khaki head that fades to a thin collar and a few thick rings of lace. Nutty and pine nose, biscuit malt and mild sweetness. Medium flavor, nutty malt, dry and resin body and a strong hoppy pine finish. Medium thick body, creamy and smooth with light carbonation. A refreshing, hoppy bitter, infinitely drinkable. Boom.

Draught at TND:  Aroma of malt, hops, citrus, and a hint of pine.  Poured orange in color with a large, creamy, loose, rocky, off-white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Hazy.  Lightly sparkling.  Good lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and light to medium bitter. Tastes of malt, hops, florals, light pine, biscuit, bread, and a hint of caramel.  Light to medium body.  Slightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Lightly sweet, lightly bitter, malt, hop, biscuit, bread finish.  A really nice local bitter.

Hazy dark gold with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of floral, citrus, light pine, toffee, and toast.  Taste of citrus, grass, some pine, and dry finish.  Nicely hopped bitter
